items.title: [bug] Django extension incompatible with DJDT
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
Django Debug Toolbar calls `settings.is_overridden()` which results in `'Settings' object has no attribute 'IS_OVERRIDDEN'`

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:

1. Start new django project and add [django debug toolbar](https://django-debug-toolbar.readthedocs.io/en/latest/installation.html) version 2.2
2. Add dynaconf to settings.py as per instructions:
```python
# HERE STARTS DYNACONF EXTENSION LOAD (Keep at the very bottom of settings.py)
# Read more at https://dynaconf.readthedocs.io/en/latest/guides/django.html
import dynaconf  # noqa

settings = dynaconf.DjangoDynaconf(__name__, environments=True, load_dotenv=True)  # noqa
# HERE ENDS DYNACONF EXTENSION LOAD (No more code below this line)
```
3. Start the development server `python manage.py runserver`

**Expected behavior**
The Django development server to start-up with no errors

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: Linux
 - Dynaconf 3.0.0

items.title: [RFC] support place-holders in configuration files
items.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

various config libraries provide various ways to integrate environment variables:

- the [node-config](https://github.com/lorenwest/node-config/wiki/Environment-Variables#custom-environment-variables) library allows a special file (e.g. `custom-environment-variables.js`) for overriding config values from specified environment variables

```js
module.exports = {
  foo: {
    bar: {
      baz: 'THIS_ENV_VAR'
    }
  }
}
```

- spring-boot allows [placeholders](https://docs.spring.io/spring-boot/docs/2.3.2.RELEASE/reference/html/spring-boot-features.html#boot-features-external-config-placeholders-in-properties) in config files that trigger replacement with either other config values or environment variables

```yaml
foo:
  bar:
    baz: ${THIS_ENV_VAR}
```

**Describe the solution you'd like**

current support in `dynaconf` for referencing environment variables looks like it requires, special naming for environment variables which could possibly be considered a [leaky-abstraction](https://www.joelonsoftware.com/2002/11/11/the-law-of-leaky-abstractions/).

for instance, the above would require an environment variable named `DYNACONF_FOO__BAR__BAZ`, where it might be a reasonable enhancement to allow something like the spring-boot strategy illustrated above which allows a placeholder syntax directly in the config files allowing arbitrary environment variable names.

other potentially interesting features of the spring-boot solution include:

- referencing other config values

```yaml
foo:
  bar:
    baz: '123'
bim:
  bam:
    boom: ${foo.bar.baz}
```

- localized defaults

```yaml
foo:
  bar:
    baz: ${OPTIONAL_ENV_VAR:some-default-value}
```

**Describe alternatives you've considered**

the existing env-var support obviously works, but the naming strategy is tightly coupled to the config solution

```
export DYNACONF_FOO__BAR__BAZ=123
```

and i thought it might be a cool feature to allow for this to be decoupled

**Additional context**

i'm a dynaconf noob, and of all the config solutions i've come across ([configparser](https://docs.python.org/3/library/configparser.html), [pyyaml](https://pyyaml.org/), [confuse](https://github.com/beetbox/confuse)), it seems to be the most flexible and functional, but i'm sure i'm not completely up to speed on all it's capabilities...

items.title: django explicit mode: settings behavior change in dynaconf >=3.0 ?
items.body:
This isn't necessarily a bug in dynaconf but ara uses dynaconf for it's django [settings.py](https://github.com/ansible-community/ara/blob/master/ara/server/settings.py) and it no longer works when using dynaconf >=3.0 :(
This is tracked in ara with issue https://github.com/ansible-community/ara/issues/149

I need help understanding the issue and finding a solution which would support both <3.0 and >=3.0. I hope that you can point me in the right direction !

I believe the use case revolves around the [Django explicit mode](https://www.dynaconf.com/django/#explicit-mode).
I've read about ``settings.populate_obj(sys.modules[__name__], ignore=locals())`` which our settings.py doesn't currently use but adding it doesn't seem to make a difference. I would had liked to rely on an example but unfortunately the two django examples aren't using the "explicit" mode (see [here](https://github.com/rochacbruno/dynaconf/blob/master/example/django_example/foo/settings.py) and [here](https://github.com/rochacbruno/dynaconf/blob/master/example/django_example_compat/foo/settings.py))

The intent is to expose a minimum amount of settings (not ALL of django's settings) to a ``settings.yaml`` file that is written out to a default settings file if it doesn't exist. In other words, the settings from the file should be loaded first and be overridden by environment variables if declared. I realize that there might be some chicken and egg going on and I'm most definitely open to feedback on how to best do this if we're doing it wrong.

**To Reproduce**

What is likely the easiest example of something that worked before 3.0 is the retrieval of the ``SECRET_KEY`` that had been implemented:
```python
import os
from django.utils.crypto import get_random_string
from dynaconf import LazySettings

BASE_DIR = os.environ.get("ARA_BASE_DIR", os.path.expanduser("~/.ara/server"))
SETTINGS_FILE = os.environ.get("ARA_SETTINGS", os.path.join(BASE_DIR, "settings.yaml"))

settings = LazySettings(
    GLOBAL_ENV_FOR_DYNACONF="ARA", ENVVAR_FOR_DYNACONF="ARA_SETTINGS", SETTINGS_MODULE_FOR_DYNACONF=SETTINGS_FILE
)
[...]
def get_secret_key():
    if not settings.get("SECRET_KEY"):
        print("[ara] No setting found for SECRET_KEY. Generating a random key...")
        return get_random_string(length=50)
    return settings.get("SECRET_KEY")

SECRET_KEY = get_secret_key()
[...]
# SECRET_KEY gets written to ~/.ara/server/settings.yaml if the file doesn't already exist.
```

The above should read like: if there is a SECRET_KEY in settings.yaml, use that. Otherwise, generate a new one which later gets written to file -- which means the next time the server is loaded, the SECRET_KEY should not be generated and instead loaded from the file.

This felt like it worked before Dynaconf 3.0 and I'm kind of stumped now. Any ideas ?

When I try to run the example from section https://www.dynaconf.com/#initialize-dynaconf-on-your-project ("Using Python only") and try to use the dict-like iteration from section https://www.dynaconf.com/#reading-settings-variables then the assertions pass but it returns a TypeError trying to iterate over the settings object.

**To Reproduce**

Run the following `dynaconf_settings.py` file in Python 3.7 (with Dynaconf 3.0.0) with the following `settings.toml` file (copied and edited from Home page).

1. Having the following folder structure

<details>
<summary> Project structure </summary>

```bash
$ tree -v
.
├── SCRIMMAGE_1.md
├── curio_examples.py
├── dynaconf_settings.py
├── ini2json.py
├── settings.toml
├── trio_cancel.py
├── trio_rib.py

0 directories, 8 files
```
</details>

2. Having the following config files:

<details>

```toml
key = "value"
a_boolean = false
number = 789  # had to edit this to match assertion above; previous value: 1234
a_float = 56.8
a_list = [1, 2, 3, 4]
a_dict = {hello="world"}

[a_dict.nested]
other_level = "nested value"
```

</details>

3. Having the following app code:

<details>
<summary> Code </summary>

**dynaconf_settings.py**
```python
from dynaconf import Dynaconf

settings = Dynaconf(
    settings_files=["settings.toml"],
)

assert settings.key == "value"
assert settings.number == 789
assert settings.a_dict.nested.other_level == "nested value"
assert settings['a_boolean'] is False
assert settings.get("DONTEXIST", default=1) == 1

for key, value in settings:                   # dict like iteration
    print(key, value)
```

</details>

4. Executing under the following environment

<details>
<summary> Execution </summary>

```bash
$ python3 --version
Python 3.7.7
$ python3 dynaconf_settings.py
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "dynaconf_settings.py", line 15, in <module>
    for key, value in settings:                   # dict like iteration
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/dynaconf/base.py", line 285, in __getitem__
    value = self.get(item, default=empty)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/dynaconf/utils/parse_conf.py", line 195, in evaluate
    value = f(settings, *args, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/dynaconf/base.py", line 377, in get
    if "." in key and dotted_lookup:
TypeError: argument of type 'int' is not iterable
```

</details>

**Expected behavior**
No exception thrown when looping over dictionary.

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: Mac OS 10.14
 - Dynaconf Version 3.0.0 (via pip3)

items.title: [bug] User warning for the missing ".local" file
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
In Dynaconf v.3.0.0rc2, a user warning is issued about the missing ".local" file, even if the settings file pointed at by the option `settings_file=...` is successfully loaded. As a result, if a user wants to load a config file named "settings", s/he is forced to create a "settings.local" file (could be empty) to get rid of the annoying warning. The `silent_errors` option doesn't have any effect on this one.

**To Reproduce**
Create a settings file without the accompanying ".local" file, and try to read a key from it by calling a `get(key)` method of the Dynaconf settings object.

**Expected behavior**
When the specified settings file is loaded, there is no need to issue a warning about the missing ".local" file.
Alternatively, provide a way to suppress such warnings.

**Environment:**
 - OS: Linux/Ubuntu 18.04
 - Dynaconf Version: 3.0.0 rc2

items.title: Community Meeting Meta Issue [BREAKING CHANGES]
items.body:
Let's discuss the breaking changes coming on Dynaconf 3.0.0 https://doodle.com/poll/ke2g4kc6mzwgtavh

There are some issues still opened for 3.0 https://github.com/rochacbruno/dynaconf/milestone/9

The highlights to be discussed are:

- **Global `settings` object is going to be deprecated**
    Users must create their own instance of dynaconf 
    **Deprecate**    
    ```py
    from dynaconf import settings
    ```
    **New recommended way**
    ```py
     # yourprogram/config.py
     settings = Dynaconf(**options)`
    ```
    **reason**
    Most users are confused about importing direct from dynaconf a singleton config object and when
    customizations via `**options` are needed they have to change the whole codebase.

- **No more default file paths** 
   Right now Dynaconf loads all files named `settings.*` 
   idea is making it explicit only via option 
   `settings_files=[list of paths or globs]`
   e.g:
   ```py
   from dynaconf import Dynaconf
   settings = Dynaconf(settings_files=["main.toml", "other.toml", "path/*.toml"])
   ```
   **reason**
   Debugging file loading is hard, permissions and other I/O problems may happen
   idea is to make explicit and raise earlier for errors.

- Envless mode will be default

  Now dynaconf has an `envless_mode`, which means it can load
  all variables direct from the main level of a file.

  ```toml
  server = 'bar.com'
  port = 5050
  ```

  This will be the default and if needed users will provide the
  list of environments.

  ```py
  settings = Dynaconf(envs=["development", "production"])
  ```

  then

  ```toml
  [default]
  server = 'bar.com'
  port = 5050
  [development]
  server = 'dev.com'
  [production]
  server = 'prod.com'
  port = 80
  ```

- **Allow parser to be changed or disabled** 
   Right now `toml` is the only parser for every variable, 
   idea is to make it configurable (and allow users to opt-out)
   **reason**
   Some users reported that wanted raw values instead of parsed 
   by toml.
   
- **dotenv will be disabled by default** 
  No more loading of `.env` unless users explicitly enables it.
  **reason**
  In some environments dotenv is already loaded by the shell tool
  
- Validators will fire by default if passed to the settings object
  No need to explicity call **settings.validators.validate()**
  if `Dynaconf(validators=[...])` is passed it will be called
  right after the initialization.

- Remove logging completely
  **reason**
  It is easier to debug using pdb/ipdb, logging right now is 
  useless.

- Allow Pydantic BaseModels as validators

items.title: Custom Loader is slow due to debug message[bug]
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
Loading of files using a custom loader is particularly slow because of a debug message that forces the file contents to be concatenated into a string

**To Reproduce**
Create a custom loader and use the existing BaseLoader (from dynaconf.loaders.base import BaseLoader) class to load the file

3. Having the following app code:

<details>
<summary> Code </summary>

```python
    for file in candidate_file_names:
        found_file = obj.find_file(file)

        if found_file:
            break
    else:
        return

    loader = BaseLoader(
        obj=obj,
        env=env,
        identifier="json",
        extensions=JSON_EXTENSIONS,
        file_reader=json_reader,
        string_reader=json_reader,
    )

    loader.load(filename=found_file, key=key, silent=True)
...
```

</details>

**Expected behavior**
The execution time should be much lower, in some cases (e.g. 20mb files) it takes more than twice the expected time

**Additional context**
The log message is the following:

<details>
<summary> Code </summary>
dynaconf/loaders/base.py (BaseLoader class, lines 154 to 161)

```python
self.obj.logger.debug(
    "{}_loader: {}[{}]{}".format(
        self.identifier,
        os.path.split(source_file)[-1],
        env,
        list(data.keys()) if is_secret else data,
    )
)
...
```
</details>

items.title: [RFC] Add support for FreeIPA Vault
items.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Currently, Dynaconf can support Hashicorp Vault. But, some systems implementing Dynaconf potentially also integrate with FreeIPA - which has it's own vault with API/CLI access. The FreeIPA Vault has the added benefit of being associated with the service/user accounts hosted from FreeIPA.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Implement FreeIPA vault integration.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
N/A

**Additional context**
Implementing FreeIPA integration could allow Katello - for example - to use Dynaconf to store secrets in FreeIPA vault.

https://www.freeipa.org/page/V4/Password_Vault_2.0#Overview
https://www.freeipa.org/page/V4/Password_Vault_2.0#Client_API

items.title: Add mount point option for vault
items.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
We are using this library for configuration and are currently moving our secrets to vault. However, there is no option to set the `mount_point`. This means it ends up using the default from the `hvac` client (`secret`). 

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Add option to set mount point via option such as `VAULT_MOUNT_POINT_FOR_DYNACONF` This is already supported in the `hvac` client, ie: 

```
client.kv.read_secret_version(path=vault_secrets_path, mount_point='global/kv')
```

items.title: Default values do not seem to resolve correctly
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
Default values do not seem to resolve correctly

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:

settings.toml:
```
[default]
a = 100
b = "BB"

[default.namespace]
b = "Default namespace B"

[development]
a = 200

[development.namespace]
a = "DEV Namespace A"
```

The simplest python program of:

```
from dynaconf import settings

print(settings.A)
print(settings.B)
print(settings.NAMESPACE.A)
print(settings.NAMESPACE.B)
```

Gives me:

```
200       # Looks OK, defined in development
BB        # Looks OK, missing in development but defined in default
DEV Namespace A    # Looks OK, defined in the development.namespace section
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/mnt/data/projects/pkh/rapidxmm/repos/backend/backend/src/.venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/dynaconf/utils/boxing.py", line 15, in __getattr__
    return super(DynaBox, self).__getattr__(n_item, *args, **kwargs)
  File "/mnt/data/projects/pkh/rapidxmm/repos/backend/backend/src/.venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/box.py", line 525, in __getattr__
    raise BoxKeyError(str(err))
box.BoxKeyError: "'DynaBox' object has no attribute 'b'"
```

I was expecting the `settings.NAMESPACE.B` to be picked up from my `default.namespace` section, in the same manner that `settings.B` was picked from `default`, but it does not!

Am I missing a configuration option to turn on such a behavior, or is this indeed a bug?

Thanks!

If you specify a null value for a variable in a yaml config file and when you try to use this variable you will get "variable does not exists" error.

The same issue should appear when using nulls in vault (since it's a JSON).

**To Reproduce**
The following python snippet can be used to reproduce the issue:

```python
from dynaconf.base import Settings
settings = Settings()
settings['name'] = 'Hello'
settings['nulled_name'] = None

print(settings['name'])
print(settings['nulled_name'])
```

The output is:

```
Hello
Traceback (most recent call last):

    raise KeyError("{0} does not exists".format(item))
KeyError: 'nulled_name does not exists'
```

items.title: [bug] RuntimeError: dictionary changed size during iteration when using @del within dynaconf_merge logic

```
new = {"a": 1}

for k, v in new.items():
    new.pop(k, None)
```

```
default:

    B: 2
development:

    dynaconf_merge:

```

**Expected behavior**
No RuntimeError, key marked with `@del` is removed from merge result

items.title: [RFC] add FlaskDynaconf.load_extensions method.
items.body:
Given:

```toml
[default]
EXTENSIONS = [
    "project.ext.appearance.init_app",
    "flask_bootstrap:Bootstrap",
    "flask_simplelogin:SimpleLogin",
]
```

To make Flask to load that extensions we can do

```py
from importlib import import_module
from dynaconf import FlaskDynaconf
from flask import Flask

def load_extensions(app):
    for extension in app.config.EXTENSIONS:
        ext = import_module(extension)
        ext(app)

app = Flask()
FlaskDynaconf(app)
load_extensions(app)
```

## Proposal

`load_extensions` function will be part of `FlaskDynaconf`

```py
from dynaconf import FlaskDynaconf
from flask import Flask
app = Flask()
FlaskDynaconf(app)
...
...
app.config.load_extensions(key="EXTENSIONS")

# alternativelly
app.config.load_extensions(key="EXTENSIONS", extensions=[..., ...])
```

items.title: Inconsistent/undefined behavior in when accessing settings with lower-case names

milestone.description:
- Lean core
- Do not break compatibility (or offer easy workarounds)
- Resolve inconsistences and usability
- Most of the features enabled via plugin system like pytest
- Build plugin community

items.body:
Hey, I'd like to discuss this behavior I just encountered when I was using a Dynaconf Settings object alongside a regular dict, and trying to use the same code for accessing both of them.  Assuming there is a Dynaconf Settings instance named `settings` that has the parameter `PORT` set to 8080, the following behavior can be observed when accessing the parameter:

1. Using key ("bracket") notation:

    ```python
    >>> settings["PORT"]
    8080 
    
    >>> settings["port"]
    8080
    ```

1. Using .get:

    ```python
    >>> settings.get("PORT")
    8080 
    
    >>> settings.get("port")
    8080
    ```

1. Using attribute ("dot") notation:

    ```python
    >>> settings.PORT  
    8080 
    
    >>> settings.port
    …
    AttributeError: 'Settings' object has no attribute 'port'
    ```

The outlier here is obviously the lower-case dot notation, right? But here is where the behavior actually differs from a dictionary:

```python
>>> "PORT" in settings
True

>>> "port" in settings
False
```

Taking into account _all_ returned results above, the last statement should _also_ respond `True`, because it contradicts the "dict-like" ways to access it (`.get` and key notation) where the lower-case variable is indeed "in settings".

As far as I can see the documentation does not mention this, which is why I'd like to propose defining a consistent behavior regarding upper/lower-casing parameters in Dynaconf. IMHO the behavior should be consistent across all access patterns, and I think Dynaconf should internally be case-insensitive and support both lower-case and upper-case parameter access. The casing should only matter on environment variables (always to be upper-case) where lower-case variables don't generally work.

What do you think?

items.title: [bug] ENV_FOR_DYNACONF overrides from_env
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
When ENV_FROM_DYNACONF is set, from_env ignores it's env parameter and uses ENV_FROM_DYNACONF instead.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:

1. Having the following config files:

<details>
<summary> Config files </summary>

**.env**

```bash
ENV_FOR_DYNACONF=development
```


**settings.toml**  

```toml
[default]
somekey = "test"

[development]
thisis = "development"

[production]
thisis = "production"
```
</details>

3. Having the following app code:

<details>
<summary> Code </summary>

**main.py**
```python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from dynaconf import settings

print(f'Current env: {settings.current_env}')

print(f'Dev is: {settings.THISIS}')

print(f'''Production is: {settings.from_env('production').THISIS}''')

exit()
```

</details>

4. Executing under the following environment

<details>
<summary> Execution </summary>

```bash
$ ./main.py
```

</details>

**Expected behavior**
The env passed directly to from_env overrides the one set via .env file


Current env: DEVELOPMENT
Dev is: development
Production is: production

items.title: [RFC] Add https://t.me/dynaconf as a channel/badge on README and docs.
items.body:
Add https://t.me/dynaconf link as a badge on README and also on docs/index.rst

This the channel for users and collaborators.

items.title: [RFC] Allow customization of validation message
items.body:
Request from @bmbouter https://github.com/pulp/pulpcore/pull/358#issuecomment-548439319

The error message I think will be confusing to users because most users use Pulp without much awareness they are also using dynaconf. The error message is: 
```
dynaconf.validator.ValidationError: CONTENT_ORIGIN is required in env DEVELOPMENT
```

We would like to be able to specify custom validator message

```python
from dynaconf import settings, Validator

settings.validators.register(
    # Ensure some password cannot exist
    Validator('CONTENT_ORIGIN', must_exist=True, message="Custom Error Message"),
)

settings.validators.validate()
```

items.title: What to do with declarations like "!!python/object/new:box.BoxList" ?
items.body:
We use dynaconf to template out a default configuration file in YAML and we've started seeing declarations like these:
```
default:
  ALLOWED_HOSTS: !!python/object/new:box.BoxList
    listitems:
    - ::1
    - 127.0.0.1
    - localhost
    state:
      box_class: &id001 !!python/name:box.Box ''
      box_options: {}
      box_org_ref: 140462933942512
```

I realize these are coming from python-box but they weren't present until recently.
They don't look mandatory ? A settings file without these seem to work as well.

It unfortunately makes the templated file less readable and definitely not human writable.

items.title: Is it a good idea to store class instance reference into dynaconf ?
items.body:
I think the answer is no but I was searching how dynaconf persist settings across import in multiple files and I don't found the answer.

Example:
```
settings.set("CLASSES.database", Database())
```

The advantage is the code simplification because I do not need to pass the instance on every classes of my project.

Maybe it's dangerous due to the garbage collector ?

Sorry if that seems like a stupid question but I can't found a real answer on the web (I found some python module like weakref, pickle etc... but does not seem to do the trick properly).

PS: I love your work, I can now remove a lot of configparser code and improve readability !

items.title: [bug] Exception when getting non existing dotted keys with default value
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
Using settings.get(key, default) with a non-existing key - depending on the default value - produces an exception.
Am I missing something obvious?

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:

1. Having the following folder structure

- app.py
- config.py

2. Having the following config files:
- config.py 

3. Having the following app code:

<details>
<summary> Code </summary>

**app.py**
```python
from dynaconf import settings as s

s.load_file("config.py")

print("As dict:")
print(s.as_dict())

print("Existing key:", s.get("foo.bar"))

print("With 0 as default:", s.get("non.existing.key", 0))

print("With list as default:", s.get("non.existing.key", [1, 2, 3]))

```

**config.py**
```python
FOO = {
  "bar": "hello"
}
```

</details>

4. Executing under the following environment

```bash

$ python
Python 3.7.3 (default, Mar 27 2019, 16:54:48)
[Clang 4.0.1 (tags/RELEASE_401/final)] :: Anaconda, Inc. on darwin

$ pip freeze

urllib3==1.25.6

$ python app.py
As dict:
{'FOO': {'bar': 'hello'}}
Existing key: hello
With 0 as default: 0
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "app.py", line 12, in <module>
    print("With list as default:", s.get("non.existing.key", [1, 2, 3]))
  File "/Users/me/Stuff/dynaconf/pyenv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/dynaconf/base.py", line 296, in get
    dotted_key=key, default=default, cast=cast, fresh=fresh
  File "/Users/me/Stuff/dynaconf/pyenv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/dynaconf/base.py", line 275, in _dotted_get
    return self._dotted_get(".".join(keys), default=default, **kwargs)
  File "/Users/me/Stuff/dynaconf/pyenv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/dynaconf/base.py", line 265, in _dotted_get
    result = self.get(name, default=default, **kwargs)
  File "/Users/me/Stuff/dynaconf/pyenv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/dynaconf/base.py", line 312, in get
    data = store.get(key, default)
AttributeError: 'BoxList' object has no attribute 'get'
```

**Expected behavior**
No exception and no dependency on the default value

 - OS: Linux/Ubuntu18.04 and MacOS 10.14.6
 - Dynaconf Version: 2.2.0/wheel

items.title: [RFC] Better merging standards
items.body:
Right now There are some ways for merging existing data structures in Dynaconf

- Using `dynaconf_merge` mark
- Using `__` double underlines for existing dictionaries and nested data
- Using MERGE_ENABLED_FOR_DYNACONF var to merge everything globally

All the 3 existing ways has limitations.

- `dynaconf_merge` is limited because it works only for 1st level vars
- `__` works only for data nested under a dictionary
- MERGE_ENABLED can break stuff in Django config.

# New standards for merging.

> **NOTE** All the above will keep working, we will try to not break backwards compatibility.

Although we are going to explicitly recommend only the new standards on explicit ways for merging that meets:

- Optional Granular control of which data is being merged
- Control of global merge feature per file
- Works also via environment variables
- Merge at any level in the nested structures
- Can merge any data type like dicts and lists

# The merge mark

Historically dynaconf is being using `@marks` for some special environment variables, we will introduce a new one: `@merge` for env vars and improve the existing `dynaconf_merge` for regular files.

## Merging files.

A `settings.yaml` file exists in your project:

```yaml
default:
  name: Bruno
  colors:
    - red
    - green
  data:
    links:
        twitter:  rochacbruno
        site: brunorocha.org
```

which will  add to `settings.__dict__` object data like:

```py
{
  "NAME": "Bruno",
  "COLORS": ["red", "green"],
  "DATA": {"links": {"twitter": "rochacbruno", "site": "brunorocha.org"}}
}
```

In a `settings.local.yaml` we want now to contribute to that existing data we have 2 options

### Merge the whole file

adding a `dynaconf_merge: true` to the root level of the file.

`settings.local.yaml`
```yaml
dynaconf_merge: true
default:
  colors:
    - blue
  data:
    links:
        github: rochacbruno.github.io
```

Then `settings.__dict__`

```py
{
  "NAME": "Bruno",
  "COLORS": ["red", "green", "blue"],
  "DATA": {"links": {"twitter": "rochacbruno", "site": "brunorocha.org", "github": "rochacbruno.github.io"}}
}
```

### Granular control of which variable is being merged

If we want to merge only specific variables we have to enclose data under a `dynaconf_merge` key, for example we want to override everything but we want to merge the colors.

`settings.local.yaml`
```yaml
default:
  name: Other Name
  colors:
    dynaconf_merge:
      - yellow
      - pink
  data:
    links:
        site: other.com
```

if it was `toml`

```toml
[default]
name = "Other Name"

[default.colors]
dynaconf_merge = ["yellow","pink"]

[default.data.links]
site = "other.com"
```

So dynaconf will do pre-processing of every file and for each `dynaconf_merge` it will call the merge pipeline.

Result on `settings.__dict__`
```py
{
  "NAME": "Other Name",  # <-- overwritten
  "COLORS": ["red", "green", "yellow", "pink"],  # <-- merged
  "DATA": {"links": {"site": "other.com"}}  # <-- overwritten
}
```
## Dunder merging

Dunder merging continues to work as a shortcut when the data you want to merge is behind a nested datastructure

```yaml
default:
  data__links__telegram: t.me/rochacbruno  # <-- Calls set('data.links', "t.me/rochacbruno")
```
or `toml`
```toml
[default]
data__links__telegram = "t.me/rochacbruno"  # <-- Calls set('data.links', "t.me/rochacbruno")
```

or `.env`

```bash
export DYNACONF_DATA__links__telegram="t.me/rochacbruno"  # <-- Calls set('data.links', "t.me/rochacbruno")
```

## @merge mark

For envvars the `@merge` will mark as it follows the standard for the other envvar markers.
and it can also be used in regular files

`.yaml`
```yaml
default:
  name: Jon # <-- Overwritten
  colors: "@merge blue"   # <-- Calls .append('blue')
  colors: "@merge ['blue', 'white']" # <-- Calls .extend(['blue', 'white'])
```

`.env`

```bash
export DYNACONf_NAME=Erik   # <-- Overwritten

export DYNACONF_COLORS="@merge ['blue']"   # <-- Calls .extend(['blue'])
export DYNACONF_COLORS="@merge ['blue', 'white']"  # <-- Calls .extend(['blue', 'white'])
export DYNACONF_COLORS="@merge blue"  # <-- Calls .append('blue')
export DYNACONF_COLORS="@merge blue,white"  # <-- Calls .extend('blue,white'.split(','))

export DYNACONF_DATA="@merge {foo='bar'}"  # <-- Calls .update({"foo": "bar"})
export DYNACONF_DATA="@merge foo=bar"  # <-- Calls ['foo'] = "bar"
```

This, according to my team lead, is a common practice to have `filename.local.yaml` file that can override values in `filename.yaml` file where `filename` is same.

items.title: global merge going away?
items.body: I set up our application on dynaconf 1 in such a way that it looks at multiple configuration files and conf files further down in the stack will override those higher up.  This relies on the MERGE_ENABLED_FOR_DYNACONF setting to work since most of our configuration is organized in objects.   After upgrading to 2.1.1 I see the deprecation notice and a suggestion to move to locally specified override flags.  It seems like this new approach is incompatible with the way I've set things up.  Is there some kind of workaround I can do with the new system aside from adding `dynaconf_merge=true` to every object in the conf?

items.title: [bug] (or unexpected automatism) in Django explicit mode
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
If using the Django extension in explicit mode, as per the documentation, variables in settings.py that have a same-named counterpart in the configuration file are still overridden, even if they are defined as a lazy setting.

**To Reproduce**
Use the example for Explicit Mode from the Django documentation for Dynaconf.

Then, change the setting name used for DEBUG to something else:

```
DEBUG = _settings.get('debug.enabled', False)
```

In your TOML configuraiton file, do something like:

```
[default.debug]
enabled = false
```

The DEBUG setting will now turn out to be a Box config object containing the whole default.debug dict, rather than only the value of default.debug.enabled.

This *might* be the expected behaviour, if it is intended that in explicit mode, settings variables are also set automatically if they exist, but in that case, it should really be documented.

Please mind that above example causes a security issue because a non-empty Box config object evaluates to a truthy value.

items.title: [RFC] Add method to load_keys
items.body:
**Problem**
Suppose we have a secret store that has layout like this:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8180469/63630714-f763a580-c5eb-11e9-957b-4fe469a9962b.png)

I would like to have a method to list all the keys. 

**Solution**
I have tried following piece of code in Vault_loader.py as:
```
def load_keys(obj, path):
    client = get_client(obj)
    return client.list('/secret/metadata/{}'.format(path))
```
It uses `/secret/metadata` endpoint for Vault and returns the dict that also contains keys. 

**Sample output:**
```
{'request_id': '<redacted>',
 'lease_id': '',
 'renewable': False,
 'lease_duration': 0,
 'data': {'keys': ['secret1', 'secret2', 'secret3']},
 'wrap_info': None,
 'warnings': None,
 'auth': None}

```
I can then do 
```
vault_loader.load_keys(settings, 'sample/')['data']['keys']                                                    
['secret1', 'secret2', 'secret3']
```

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
IMHO, It only fits to use this solution because we have number of different credentials we want to store and retrieve. Another solution would be to dump all credentials under one secret in JSON format like this 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8180469/63630822-e6fffa80-c5ec-11e9-8108-1668fffb14f0.png)

The problem with that is if we have a lot of credentials(keys) in one secret(or environment) then updating one key would mean that I have to load entire data and then update relevant key and write the entire data again. 


**Additional context**
You may contact me on Google Chat/email(Red Hat) if you want to discuss our use case. 
I am fairly new to Vault/Dynaconf, excuse if my understanding is different that how this all is intended to be used.

items.title: [RFC] Allow dotted environment variables
items.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Parameters defined in environment variables cannot be accessed with dotted key notation in the same way as parameters defined in settings files, which prevents overriding dotted key parameters with environment variables. 

**Example:** Environment variable `DYNACONF_SERVICE_PORT` cannot be accessed via `settings['SERVICE.PORT']`. Instead, it must be accessed via `settings['SERVICE_PORT']`.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
One solution would be to use a designated sequence of characters to symbolize a dot separator, possibly two consecutive underscores ( `__` ). This character sequence could be configurable (eg `ENVVAR_DOT_SEPARATOR_FOR_DYNACONF`).

**Example:** Environment variable `DYNACONF_SERVICE__PORT` could be accessed via `settings['SERVICE.PORT']`, and would override any `service.port` parameter defined in a settings file.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
An alternative to this could be to simply match either dotted or non-dotted key values to the correlated environment variable. As a note, this is how Spring Framework handles this feature.

**Example:** Environment variable `DYNACONF_SERVICE_PORT` could be accessed via `settings['SERVICE.PORT']` or via `settings['SERVICE_PORT']`, and would override any `service.port` or `service_port` parameter defined in a settings file.

**Additional context**
This would be especially nice for:
- allowing natural grouping of related settings (eg `service.host` and `service.port`)
- allowing overriding of existing parameters defined in a settings file
- accessing environment variables via object dot notation (eg `settings.SERVICE.PORT`)

items.title: Missing an isolated namespace [RFC]
items.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
A clear and concise description of what the problem is. Ex. I'm always frustrated when [...]

The Settings object should have a way of accessing and traversing the keys loaded from the settings files without having all of the Dynaconf options in there. When I call `config.keys()` I'm getting `['SETTINGS_MODULE', 'PROJECT_ROOT_FOR_DYNACONF', 'SETTINGS_MODULE_FOR_DYNACONF', ...`

**Describe the solution you'd like**
A clear and concise description of what you want to happen.

Ideally when you call `keys()` and similar methods, it should only return values in the namespaces loaded by the file. Even if it involved doing this `config.current_env.keys()` it would be fine.

Also, having methods of exporting the current (possibly modified) settings would be nice. Basically I would like to be able to do this:

```python 
with open(output_file, 'w') as f:
    yaml.dump(config.environments['development'].as_dict(), f)
```

And have that write out a flattened version of the development namespace.

**test.py**  and **subdir/test.py**
```python
from dynaconf import settings
print(settings.ENV_FOR_DYNACONF)
```

</details>

4. Executing under the following environment

<details>
<summary> Execution </summary>

```bash
# conda install with python 3.7.3 and ipyhton 7.4.0 

$ python test.py        
PYTHON_WORKS_IPYTHON_DOES_NOT

$ python subdir/test.py 
PYTHON_WORKS_IPYTHON_DOES_NOT

$ cd subdir/

subdir$ python test.py        
PYTHON_WORKS_IPYTHON_DOES_NOT

subdir$ cd ..

$ ipython ./test.py 
PYTHON_WORKS_IPYTHON_DOES_NOT

$ ipython ./subdir/test.py   
PYTHON_WORKS_IPYTHON_DOES_NOT

$ cd subdir/

subdir$ ipython ./test.py 
DEVELOPMENT
```

</details>

**Expected behavior**
Last command should output PYTHON_WORKS_IPYTHON_DOES_NOT
(works with dynaconf 1.2.1)

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: Linux/Ubuntu18.04
 - conda 4.6.14
 - python 3.7.3
 - ipython 7.4.0/7.5.0
 - Dynaconf Version 2.0.1/pip

items.title: Error using multiple configs files from different folders, having a default file (not merged)
items.body:
I need to read from multiple settings file and also a common setting file (aka defaults).
To do so i'm setting the ENV variable to the two file paths

```python
os.environ['SETTINGS_FILE_FOR_DYNACONF'] = '<abs_path>/config/default.toml, <abs_path>/config1/settings.toml'
```

default.toml
```ini
[development]
VAR_DFT = "default_dev"

[production]
VAR_DFT = "default_prod"
```

settings.toml
```ini
[development]
VAR1 = 'config1_dev'

[production]
VAR1 = 'config1_prod'
```

```python

import os
from dynaconf import settings

from config  import __file__ as config_file
from config1 import __file__ as config1_file
from config2 import __file__ as config2_file

default = os.path.join(os.path.dirname(config_file), 'default-settings.toml')
f1 = os.path.join(os.path.dirname(config1_file), 'settings.toml')
f2 = os.path.join(os.path.dirname(config2_file), 'settings.toml')

print('using config 1')
os.environ['SETTINGS_FILE_FOR_DYNACONF'] = "{}, {}".format(default, f1)

print('development')
settings.setenv('development')
print(settings.VAR_DFT) #no error
print(settings.VAR1) #gives me error

print('changing to production')
settings.setenv('production')
print(settings.VAR1)

print('----')

print('using config 2')
os.environ['SETTINGS_FILE_FOR_DYNACONF'] = "{},{}".format(default, f2)

print('development')
settings.setenv('development')
print(settings.VAR1)

print('changing to production')
settings.setenv('production')
print(settings.VAR1)

```

It gives me error `AttributeError: 'Settings' object has no attribute 'VAR1'` trying to access VAR1... so the more specific setting and not the default...
It seems like it's not merging the two configurations.

Is it possibile, am i totally on the wrong path?

items.title: [RFC] dynaconf list command should not show internal variables
items.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

When I run `dynaconf list` command line it shows all the variables I defined on my `settings.toml` file but it also shows dynaconf internal variables like `ENV_FOR_DYNACONF`, `RENAMED_VARS`, `ENVVAR_PREFIX` etc...

**Describe the solution you'd like**
I would like it by default to show only user defined settings when I run `dynaconf list` and the internal variables will show only if I pass `--all|-a` as in `dynaconf list -a`

items.title: [RFC] include pytest integration tests for Redis and Vault
items.body:
Currently `Redis` and `Vault` features are skipped from unittests/coverage

https://github.com/rochacbruno/dynaconf/blob/b6ab9de2c7dfc1fe46dae2221d27b15534583503/.coveragerc#L11-L12

We are doing only `Functional` test cases by running the `example/` test cases.

https://github.com/rochacbruno/dynaconf/blob/b6ab9de2c7dfc1fe46dae2221d27b15534583503/Makefile#L82-L94

We need to evaluate this fixtures 
https://github.com/lovelysystems/lovely-pytest-docker 

and see if it works to have unittests for Redis and Vault.

items.title: Correct usage of ENVVAR_PREFIX_ vs. ENV_
items.body:
I think some clarification is required on the different use-cases of the new ENVVAR_PREFIX vs.  using ENV. There are multiple occurrences throughout dynaconf that are very confusing and use ENVVAR_PREFIX where I would have expected ENV to be used, for example:

* https://github.com/rochacbruno/dynaconf/blob/1bb2c39ae6a39cbbd32ca8ef39ef7ea5732a9418/dynaconf/base.py#L842
* https://github.com/rochacbruno/dynaconf/blob/1bb2c39ae6a39cbbd32ca8ef39ef7ea5732a9418/dynaconf/contrib/flask_dynaconf.py#L50
* https://github.com/rochacbruno/dynaconf/blob/e48521790a72fa4756a9d0eb8d715da562642f25/dynaconf/cli.py#L468-L469
* https://github.com/rochacbruno/dynaconf/blob/3ba4ed1f0a929289a111157e1d6c06b2d072925a/dynaconf/loaders/base.py#L125

These all seem to expect a value that is actually the "working environment" (we discussed the difference in #166), yet they *use* the environment variable prefix.

items.title: [RFC] rename SETTINGS_MODULE_FOR_ to SETTINGS_FILE_FOR_
items.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

Initially dynaconf loaded only python modules, hence the variable is called `SETTINGS_MODULE_FOR_DYNACONF` but now dynaconf can load files.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

rename it to `SETTINGS_FILE_FOR_DYNACONF`

**Additional context**
Keep old variable working

items.title: [RFC] Rename GLOBAL_ENV_ to ENV_PREFIX_ ?
items.body:
In the beginning dynaconf supported changing working environment for env vars and then it made sense to name it `GLOBAL_ENV_FOR_DYNACONF`.

But now, this variable is used **only** to control the environment variable prefix and the name is not good, the **global** in it can confuse people.

I suggest:

Rename `GLOBAL_ENV_FOR_DYNACONF` to `ENV_PREFIX_FOR_DYNACONF` then the name will be clear.

Renaming will not break compatibility, the old wll still work but users will see a `WARNING` message.

Comments?

items.title: Release Schedule
items.body:
# Dynaconf Release Schedule

> We use `semver`

- The `.z` (patch) will be released:
  - ASAP if a bug is fixed or security issue
  - Monthly (second monday of the month) whenever we have a `delta` diff from latest release
      - (in other words: if there are no changes no release, if changes there are release)

- The `.y.` (minor) will be released:
  - When we have no pending `.z` release
  - Monthly when a new feature was included (which is not happening for 2.x read #154)
  - ASAP when the new feature has an user **emergency** request
  > NOTE: If `.y.` is released before, than pensing `.z` should be bumped.
  
- The `x` (major) will be released
  - When breaking changes or disruptive feature is added
  - Developers will decide the best time/date
  - Will be released by developers judgement after heavy testing
  - Will have at least `a week` on `Release Canditate` to get customers feedback 

## Next `.z` release

2.0.3 - May 20, 2019

Issues:

items.title: IMPORTANT NOTES TO CONTRIBUTORS
items.body:
# Dynaconf 2.+ contribution note

Dynaconf 2.0.0 has been released (Apr, 8, 2019) , this release is a big refactor and improvements based on notes from Dynaconf users.

Now we expect the 2.x.x releases to be bug fixes only, **new features** will **not be added** to 2.x.x releases. So this stream is accepting

- Bug fixes
- Documentation Improvement
- Typo fixing

Why?

**Dynaconf** started small, and now it is turning into a **big** heavily used library, our hopes is to have it as a **de facto** configuration lib for Python.

When doing the 2.0.0 refactor to address common issues and add new features, it becomes evident that the code it now too big, dynaconf is doing too many things right now **AND THAT IS AWESOME**

But that level of **UNEXPECTED AWESOMENESS** also means that things may now become more difficult to maintain, and there is one **VERY IMPORTANT** guideline on this project.

**WE KEEP BACKWARDS COMPATIBILITY**

Configs are important, problems on config will affect the whole software, so we have this idea of keeping compatibility, when we want to remove a feature we simply **deprecate** the functionality by warnings and add the new one.

Manual intervention is **OK**, we can ask users to change a config variable, to export something, to make few adjusts to make current implementation working, but we do not want to leave users without options.

## So Dynaconf 3.0.0

As said, 2.x.x will have only bug fixes and development focus are now on **3.0.0** this release has some goals:

- Have a lean dynaconf core, only basic stuff installed on `pip install dynaconf`
- Features will be based on a **Plugin System** (like pytest does) instead of **_FOR_DYNACONF** env vars.
- Users will install only the plugins they want to use like `dynaconf-yaml`, `dynaconf-redis`, `dynaconf-schema`, `dynaconf-merge` etc...
- Do not break current compatibility `pip install dynaconf-legacy` for users who do not want to migrate from 2.x.x, legacy with only bug fixes will be there.

## How do I contribute to this awesome idea?

Milestone 2.9.0 is for issues we need to get done before starting the development of 3.0.0 stream

https://github.com/rochacbruno/dynaconf/milestone/4

MIlestone 3.0.0 is to start working when requisites are finished.

https://github.com/rochacbruno/dynaconf/milestone/3

## The development workflow

As said, we do not want to break compatibility, so there is **NO BRANCHING** branching is `hell` we do not want cherry picks.

We want to add new functionalities to **master** without breaking current implementation for milestone 2.9.0, that will be possible bu using the `dynaconf-legacy` **new package** as dependency, and there is where we will migrate the old stuff to.

After 2.9.0 is completed, we start working on **3.0.0** which means

- Remove legacy dependency (users will need to install it explicitly if want)
- Write new plugins

All contributions are very welcome.

items.title: `dynaconf_merge` doesn't appear to work on Jupyter notebook

milestone.description: This release will include new `merge` functionality, more documentation for `includes`, new envvars for loader configuration, yaml safe loader, bug fixes, Django integration improvement

items.body:
I am on Jupyter notebook through Anaconda distribution on Windows 10.
```
from platform import python_version
python_version()
# yields 3.7.1
```
Here are my files:
```
#.env
# empty file; I also tried ENV_FOR_DYNACONF="DEVELOPMENT" but that doesn't make any difference
#.secrets.yaml
development:
  section1:
    fieldA: "abc"
    fieldB: "bcd"
    fieldC: 1
    host: "11.11.11.11" # fake host
    dynaconf_merge: true

# settings.yaml
default:
  section1:
    scheme: "http"
    base_url: "some.site.com/REST"
```
Here is the code and output I get:
```
from dynaconf import settings
config = settings.get("SECTION1")
print(settings.current_env)
print(config)

# Output:
DEVELOPMENT
{'FieldA' : 'abc', 'FieldB' : 'bcd', 'FieldC' : 1, 'host' : '11.11.11.11', 'dynaconf_merge' : True }

# Expected
DEVELOPMENT
{'FieldA' : 'abc', 'FieldB' : 'bcd', 'FieldC' : 1, 'host' : '11.11.11.11', 'scheme' : 'http', 'base_url' : 'some.site.com/REST' }
```

So it appears the settings loader isn't able to recognize `dynaconf_merge` as one of its special markers and is simply passing it out as a field of the settings object requested. So obviously, no merge is happening either.

items.title: RFC: Template Substitutions - dynaconf-render-template plugin

milestone.description:
- Lean core
- Do not break compatibility (or offer easy workarounds)
- Resolve inconsistences and usability
- Most of the features enabled via plugin system like pytest
- Build plugin community

items.body:
Require: #146 

## Allow template substitutions

There are 2 types of variables that would be useful to have access within dynaconf settings

- Environment Variables `${HOME}`, `${PWD}`
- Dynaconf variables `settings.get('value')`, `settings.ROOT_PATH_FOR_DYNACONF`

When setting a new variable it would be nice to have access to that vars like using special marker `$D{}` or `@D{}` (to be defined).

To avoid overhead, this feature must be enabled via plugin.

```python
pip install dynaconf-template-render
```

```yaml
default:
  databases:
    default:
      name: foo_database
      driver: sqlite3
      file: $D{ROOT_PATH_FOR_DYNACONF}/foo.db
   conf_location: $D{HOME}/.config/foo/  
```

Then after executing the loaders (the bottom of `.execute_loaders` method) there will be a `plugin_hook` which will be called having `obj` on context, then plugin can make changes to `obj` (in place)

items.title: Can't set custom 'settings_module' value
items.body:
Hi!

I'm trying to use your (awesome looking library) for the first time and unfortunately having a lot of problems. I understand that #74 is still open and up for discussion so I wanted to explicitly set the settings module file to be sure it's read correctly, but no matter what I try it just doesn't work.

```python
from pathlib import Path

from dynaconf import LazySettings

settings = LazySettings()
settings.configure(settings_module=str(Path(__file__).parent / "settings.yaml"))
```

I added a couple of print methods to try and see what's going on - the 'patched' code:

```python
class LazySettings(LazyObject):
	# ...
    def configure(self, settings_module=None, **kwargs):
        compat_kwargs(kwargs)
        kwargs.update(self._kwargs)
        print("1", settings_module)
        self._wrapped = Settings(settings_module=settings_module, **kwargs)
        print("2", self._wrapped.SETTINGS_MODULE)

# ...

class Settings(object):
	# ...
    def __init__(self, settings_module=None, **kwargs):  # pragma: no cover
		# ...

        compat_kwargs(kwargs)
        print("3", settings_module)
        if settings_module:
            self.set('SETTINGS_MODULE', settings_module)
        for key, value in kwargs.items():
            self.set(key, value)
        # execute loaders only after setting defaults got from kwargs
        self._defaults = kwargs
        self.execute_loaders()
        print("4", self.SETTINGS_MODULE)
```

And the result of importing that settings variable:

```python
from ds import settings
1 /absolute/path/to/settings.yaml
3 /absolute/path/to/settings.yaml
4 settings.py,.secrets.py,settings.toml,settings.tml,.secrets.toml,.secrets.tml,settings.yaml,settings.yml,.secrets.yaml,.secrets.yml,settings.ini,settings.conf,settings.properties,.secrets.ini,.secrets.conf,.secrets.properties,settings.json,.secrets.json
2 settings.py,.secrets.py,settings.toml,settings.tml,.secrets.toml,.secrets.tml,settings.yaml,settings.yml,.secrets.yaml,.secrets.yml,settings.ini,settings.conf,settings.properties,.secrets.ini,.secrets.conf,.secrets.properties,settings.json,.secrets.json

```

So even though `settings_module` is correctly passed to `Settings`, it the `self.set('SETTINGS_MODULE', settings_module)` seems to disregard it completely.

I had a simillar experience when trying to set `DYNACONF_SETTINGS` instead:

```python
settings = LazySettings()
os.environ['DYNACONF_SETTINGS'] = str(Path(__file__).parent / "settings.yaml")
settings._setup()
```

```python
from ds import settings
3 None
4 settings.py,.secrets.py,settings.toml,settings.tml,.secrets.toml,.secrets.tml,settings.yaml,settings.yml,.secrets.yaml,.secrets.yml,settings.ini,settings.conf,settings.properties,.secrets.ini,.secrets.conf,.secrets.properties,settings.json,.secrets.json
```

Am I doing something wrong? It seems like a really standard use case.

Any help or pointers would be much appreciated.

items.title: Add arbitrary layer overrides

milestone.description:
- Lean core
- Do not break compatibility (or offer easy workarounds)
- Resolve inconsistences and usability
- Most of the features enabled via plugin system like pytest
- Build plugin community

items.body:
It would be nice if we could add arbitrarily layered config options at runtime, especially when working with configs across modules. For example:
```yaml
default:
    option1: blah
    option2: blah
    option3: blah

development:
    option1: blahh
    option2: blahhh

    some_variation:
        option1: blahhhhhh

    another_variation:
        option1: bla
```

```python
from dynaconf import settings as cfg

print(cfg.OPTION1) # blahh

with cfg.useopts(**cfg.SOME_VARIATION):
        print(cfg.OPTION1) # blahhhhhh

print(cfg.OPTION1) # blahh
```
And analogous to the `setenv` API
```python
print(cfg.OPTION1) # blahh

cfg.setopts('some_layer', optionA='blah', **cfg.SOME_VARIATION)
print(cfg.OPTION1) # blahhhhhh
print(cfg.OPTIONA) # blah

cfg.setopts('another_layer', optionA='blahhhhhh')
print(cfg.OPTION1) # blahhhhhh
print(cfg.OPTIONA) # blahhhhhh

cfg.removeopts('another_layer')
cfg.setopts('some_layer', **cfg.ANOTHER_VARIATION) # replace previously defined 'some_layer'
print(cfg.OPTION1) # bla
print(cfg.OPTIONA) # raise

cfg.removeopts('some_layer')
print(cfg.OPTION1) # blahh
```
It seems like a convenient generalization of the file overrides.

items.title: settings.set() does not update dynamic config values
items.body:
Hi all,

### In brief: 
I have a script that monitors [Redis sentinels](https://redis.io/topics/sentinel) and periodically updates the available master and slaves through dynaconf. These values are accessed by other python scripts to optimise specific read/write cases.

### The issue: 
calling `settings.set('keyname', python_dict_obj)` or `settings.set('keyname', json.dumps(python_dict_obj))` does not update any values in `config.toml` nor can they be accessed from other python scripts.

### Reproducing the problem
Environment variables that I set in all open terminals:
`export ENV_FOR_DYNACONF=development`
`export LANG=en_US.UTF-8`
`export LC_ALL=en_US.UTF-8`   

**Initialization of settings**
`dynaconf init -e development` - this generates `settings.toml` with dummy values in five sections **[default], [development], [staging], [production], [global]**

**Main python script (irrelevant parts omitted for clarity)**

```
from redis.sentinel import Sentinel
import redis
import json
import time
import sys
from dynaconf import settings


REDIS_SENTINELS = [("127.0.0.1", 16380), ("127.0.0.1", 16381), ("127.0.0.1", 16382)]
REDIS_CLUSTER_NAME = 'redis-cluster'

_sentinel = Sentinel(sentinels=REDIS_SENTINELS, min_other_sentinels=1, socket_timeout=0.1)


def _set_master():
    _master = _sentinel.discover_master(service_name=REDIS_CLUSTER_NAME)
    # settings.set('master', json.dumps(list(_master)))
    print("Got master ", _master)
    settings.set('master', _master)
    print(settings.exists('MASTER'))
    print(settings.MASTER)


def _set_slaves():
    _slaves = _sentinel.discover_slaves(service_name=REDIS_CLUSTER_NAME)
    # settings.set('slaves', json.dumps(_slaves))
    print("got slaves ", _slaves)
    settings.set('slaves', _slaves)
    print(settings.exists('SLAVES'))
    print(settings.SLAVES)


def main():
    while True:
        _set_master()
        _set_slaves()
        time.sleep(10)


if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()

```
**The output**

As you notice, the settings.exists() shows the values being set as True and also I can access the values
```
Got master  ('127.0.0.1', 6380)
True
['127.0.0.1', 6380]
got slaves  [('127.0.0.1', 6382), ('127.0.0.1', 6381)]
True
[['127.0.0.1', 6382], ['127.0.0.1', 6381]]
```
**When I open another terminal and run a different script or the interactive interpreter**
`export ENV_FOR_DYNACONF=development`
`export LANG=en_US.UTF-8`
`export LC_ALL=en_US.UTF-8` 

```
$python
>>> from dynaconf import settings
>>> settings.MASTER
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/anomit/.venv-py3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/dynaconf/base.py", line 100, in __getattr__
    return getattr(self._wrapped, name)
AttributeError: 'Settings' object has no attribute 'MASTER'
```

Where am I going wrong?
